text: CLOSE-UP on RINGO. He is eating a bone dry sandwich that  curls up at the end. He puts it down with disgust. He has lager glass in his hand.
(accusingly) That was fresh this morning.

We now see the pub is full of enormous cockney workmen do pints. RINGO is very much alone. He moves away from the bar towa a group that is standing together, they've an average hei of over six-foot. There is a group at a dart board. Another group is playin bar skittles and a third group is around a pin-ball table Near the bar is a shove-halfpenny board with two players. There is a caged parrot nearby.
(to Ringo) That'll be two and nine...

RINGO fumbles some change out of his pocket. A few copper fall from his hand on to the shove-halfpenny board just a the crucial point has been made. The men glare at him.  Embarrassed, he moves away and without looking, places hi glass on the skittles table just as a player swings the  string, which hits Ringo's glass. More embarrassed, RINGO backs away, unfortunately into the pin-table just as a wi score is about to be reached. He bumps it very slightly, enough to cause it to TILT. He then moves to the dart boa By this time most of the pub is staring at him. With grea style he takes the darts. The first throw goes into a che sandwich which a man is pointing in demonstration. The second we see arrive into a pint of bitter and then w see RINGO shoot the third dart and hear the sound of the  parrot shouting angrily, off. The BARMAID has had enough.
Right... On your way!
Y'what?
You heard, on your way, troublemaker!
Now the centre of attention, RINGO backs out of the pub,  followed by every eye in the place, the BARMAID and a few players following him to the door...
RINGO comes out and crosses road, watched by the POLICEMA who is now quite suspicious.

PAUL comes down the street looking about him for RINGO. I the street is an old building, the sort of place that is  highly favoured for TV rehearsals. There is a sign on the door, "TV Rehearsal Room." As PAUL draws near, a load of  actors and extras, etc. are leaving, they are in costume, they are the ones who earlier had been going to a word  rehearsal. When PAUL gets near the entrance he decides to inside.

PAUL enters and wanders about. He reaches a door, pushes open and looks in. He sees a GIRL clad in period costume. She is moving around the room and obviously acting. PAUL  watches her for a moment and then decides to go in.

PAUL goes into the room. The GIRL is in mid-flight. She i very young and lovely and completely engrossed in what sh is doing. The room is absolutely empty except for PAUL an herself. She is acting in the manner of an eighteenth-cen coquette, or, to be precise, the voice English actresses when they think they are being true to the costume period her youth however makes it all very charming.

If I believed you, sir, I might do  those things and walk those ways  only to find myself on Problem's  Path. But I cannot believe you, and  all those urgings serve only as a  proof that you will lie and lie again  to gain your purpose with me.
She dances lightly away from an imaginary lover and as sh turns she sees PAUL who is as engrossed in the scene as s was.
(surprised) Oh!
(enthusiastically) Well... go 'head, do the next bit.
Go away! You've spoilt it.
Oh, sorry I spoke.
He makes no attempt to go. He simply continues to look  steadily at the girl; then he smiles at her. She is undec what to do next.
Are you supposed to be here?
I've got you worried, haven't I?
I'm warning you, they'll be back in  a minute.
D'you know something, "They" don't  worry me at all. Anyroad, I only  fancy listening to you... that's all  but if it worries you... well...
You're from Liverpool, aren't you?
(ironically) How'd you guess?
(seriously) Oh, it's the way you talk.
(innocently) Is it... is it, really?
(suspiciously) Are you pulling my leg?
(looking her straight  in the eye) Something like that.
(unsure) I see. (airily) Do you like the play?
Yeah... I mean, sure, well, I took  it at school but I only ever heard  boys and masters saying those lines,  like, sounds different on a girl. (smiles to himself) Yeah, it's gear on a girl.
Gear?
Aye, the big hammer, smashing!
Thank you.
Don't mench... well, why don't you  give us a few more lines, like?
GIRL pouts.
You don't half slam the door in  people's faces, do you? I mean, what  about when you're playing the part,  like, hundreds of people'll see you  and ...
(cutting in) I'm not...
Oh, you're the understudy, sort of  thing?
No. (aggressively) I'm a walk-on in a fancy dress scene.  I just felt like doing those lines.
Oh, I see. You are an actress though,  aren't you?
Yes.
Aye, I knew you were.
What's that mean?
Well, the way you were spouting,  like.... (he imitates her) "I don't believe you, sir..." and  all that. Yeah, it was gear.
(dryly) The big hammer?
(smiling) Oh aye, a sledge.
But the way you did it then sounded  so phony.
No... I wouldn't say that... just  like an actress... you know.
He moves and stands about like an actress.
But that's not like a real person at  all.
Aye well, actresses aren't like real  people, are they?
They ought to be.
Oh, I don't know, anyroad up, they  never are, are they?
(teasingly) What are you?
I'm in a group... well... there are  four of us, we play and sing.
I bet you don't sound like real  people.
We do, you know. We sound like us  having a ball. It's fab.
Is it really fab or are you just  saying that to convince yourself?
What of? Look, I wouldn't do it unless  I was. I'm dead lucky 'cos I get  paid for doing something I love doing.
He laughs and with a gesture takes in the whole studio
...all this and a jam butty too!!
I only enjoy acting for myself. I  hate it when other people are let  in.
Why? I mean, which are you, scared  or selfish?
Why selfish?
Well, you've got to have people to  taste your treacle toffee.
She looks at him in surprise.

No, hang on, I've not gone daft. You  see, when I was little me mother let  me make some treacle toffee one time  in our back scullery. When I'd done  she said to me, "Go and give some to  the other kids." So, I said I would  but I thought to meself, "She must  think I'm soft." Anyroad, I was eating  away there but I wanted somebody  else to know how good it was so in  the end I wound up giving it all  away... but I didn't mind, mind,  'cos I'd made the stuff in the first  place. Well... that's why you need  other people... an audience... to  taste your treacle toffee, like.  Eh... does that sound as thickheaded  to you as it does to me?
Not really but I'm probably not a  toffee maker. How would you do those  lines of mine?
Well, look at it this way, I mean,  when you come right down to it, that  girl, she's a bit of a scrubber,  isn't she?
Is she?

Of course... Look, if she was a  Liverpool scrubber... (Paul starts acting a  Liverpool girl, he  minces about then  turns, extending his  leg) Eh, fella, you want to try pulling  the other one, it's got a full set  of bells hanging off it... Y'what?...  I know your sort, two cokes and a  packet of cheese and onion crisps  and suddenly it's love and we're  stopping in an empty shop doorway.  You're just after me body and y'can't  have it... so there!!
(shattered) And you honestly think that's what  she meant?

Oh, definitely, it sticks out a mile,  she's trying to get him to marry her  but he doesn't want... well... I  don't reckon any fella's ever wanted  to get married. But girls are like  that, clever and cunning. You've got  to laugh.
He laughs.
Well, it's nice to know you think  we're clever.
(grinning) And cunning.
And what do you do about it?
Me? Oh, I don't have the time, I'm  always running about with the lads...  no, we don't have the time.
Pity.
(not noticing the  invitation) Aye, it is but as long as you get  by, it's all right, you know... bash  on, happy valley's when they let you  stop. Anyroad, I'd better get back.
Yes.
(going) See you.
Of course.
PAUL stands at the doorway, shrugs then goes out.

In the street, workmen are collecting shovels, drinking t and doing all the things people do around building sites. RINGO mooches around. In the road is a hole with a diameter of about 3 feet, an at least 6 feet deep. RINGO looks down and a man is busil working at the bottom of the hole. He glares at RINGO. Af a moment RINGO turns away. We now see a very elegant youn lady coming towards RINGO. She is daintily avoiding a ser of puddles. RINGO has an idea and does a Sir Walter Ralei with his large Mac spreading it over one of the puddles. girl walks across it smiling graciously. RINGO proceeds w the coat to the next puddle and to the next backing gradu towards the hole. At last he spreads the coat, without noticing what he is  doing, over the hole. The girl steps onto the coat and  disappears sharply. RINGO looks down the hole where the g is held in the workman's arms. The workman rises out of t manhole until he is waist height. At this point an elegan dressed gentleman appears (the girl's husband) he looks a his wife in the workman's arms and hits the workman. RING backs away through the puddles, and is nicked by the  POLICEMAN. [Scenes 75 and 76 deleted in revision.]

head_text.subj: INTERIOR T.V. THEATRE NEAR STAGE DOOR

text: The DIRECTOR is pacing up and down the corridor. NORM is  also walking up and down, SHAKE is leaning against the wa quite unconcerned. NORM gives SHAKE a push.
Worry, will you!
SHAKE adjusts his features to a worrying expression.
(bitterly) Well, that's it, two minutes to the  final run-through... they're bound  to miss it...
I'll murder that Lennon.
But I suppose we can survive a missed  run-through as long...
...as they head up for the show. Oh  yes, well I mean it'ud be a pity to  miss the show, wouldn't it like.
Shurrup, cheerful.
The horrible prospect hits the DIRECTOR.
You don't think...
(reassuring him) They'll be here.
Oh now, they can't do that to me. (turning on Norm) It's all your fault. (overriding Norm) Oh yes it is and if they don't turn  up I wouldn't be in your shoes for  all the...
(helping out) ...tea in China. Oh you're right,  neither would I.
He steps away from NORM and stands near the DIRECTOR.
Traitor!
SHAKE nods his agreement to this assessment of his charac
Of course.
At this moment JOHN, GEORGE and PAUL enter from the stage door. They are completely unconcerned and walk past the  DIRECTOR, SHAKE and NORM.
(as he passes by) Hi Norm!
(preoccupied) Hi, our lot!
The BOYS walk on when after a moment NORM snaps to.
Our lot!
(mildly) Did you want something.
(beaming with delight) I could eat the lot of you.
You'd look gear with an apple in  your gob.
(accusingly) Do you realise you could have missed  the final run-through?
Sorry.
Eh, there's only three of them.
Aye, we were looking for Ringo. But  we realised he must have come back.
Do you realise we are on the air,  live, in front of an audience, in  forty-five minutes and you're one  short.
Control yourself or you'll spurt.  He's bound to be somewhere.
Aye, let's try the dressing room.
Everyone starts along the passage. NORM and PAUL last.
Eh, where's my grandfather?
Don't worry about him. He can look  after himself.
Aye, I suppose so.
They run after the others.
Here they are, personally signed and  handwritten by your own sweet boys.  The chance of a lifetime. Be the  envy of your less fortunate sisters!

The CAMERA PULLS back and we see GRANDFATHER is surrounde by girls who have broken from the queue and are doing a b trade with the old man. He has a large sign on which is  written: "Get your genuine autographed Beatles photograph On the edge of the crowd two POLICEMEN are trying to forc the girls back into the queue. Finally they wade through girls and confront GRANDFATHER. They look at the old man  quizzically; he stares back coldly. They indicate he shou hop it and quick but GRANDFATHER defiantly glares back at them. So with a sigh, they grab an arm each and escort th old man off.
It is the reception desk and behind it is the DESK SERGEA After a moment RINGO is dragged in by the POLICEMAN we sa him with before.
Look, I'm Ringo Starr... I've got a  show to do in a few minutes you've  got to let me go... I'm Ringo...
Sure, they all say that these days...  Anyway... I don't care who you are...  you can save that for the stipendary.  Here you are, Sarge.
What is he?
(reeling off the list) I've got a little list here. Wandering  abroad. Malicious intent. Acting in  a suspicious manner. Conduct liable  to cause a breach of the peace. You  name it, he's done it.
Oh, a little savage, is he?
A proper Aborigine.
(on his dignity) I demand to see me solicitor.
What's his name?
Oh, well if you're going to get  technical --
At that moment there is a loud series of noises off camer furious shouting and dull crashes of wood.
Hello, it's going to be one of those  nights, is it? (to policeman) Sit Charley Peace down over there.
The POLICEMAN takes RINGO to a bench and sits him down as GRANDFATHER and the two POLICEMEN who were with him enter The sign is tattered and is being lugged after them.

Well, you got me here so do your  worst but I'll take one of you with  me. (kicks the nearest  policeman) Oh, I know your game, get me in the  tiled room and out come the rubber  hoses but I'll defy you still.
Is there a fire, then?
GRANDFATHER leans across the desk and hisses at the SERGE
You ugly, great brute you, you have  sadism stamped all over your bloated  British kisser.
Eh?
I'll go on a hunger strike. I know  your caper.
The kidney punch and the rabbit-clout. The third degree a the size twelve boot ankle-tap.
What's he on about?
(squaring up) I'm soldier of the Republic, you'll  need the mahogany truncheon for this  boyo. A nation once again.
(to policemen) Get Lloyd George over there with  that mechanic in the cloth cap while  I sort this lot out.

The POLICEMEN hurtle GRANDFATHER firmly but gently over t the bench on which RINGO is sitting and then return to th desk for a whispered conference with the SERGEANT. Meanwh in full conspiratorial fashion GRANDFATHER talks to RINGO out of the side of his mouth.
Ringo, me old scout, they grabbed  yer leg for the iron too, did they?
Well I'm not exactly a voluntary  patient.
Shush! Have they roughed you up yet?
What?

(whispering) Keep your voice down, this lot'll  paste you, just for the exercise. Oh  they're a desperate crew of drippings  and they've fists like matured hams  for pounding defenceless lads like  you.
(disturbed) Have they?
That sergeant's a body-blow veteran  if ever I measured one. One of us  has got to escape. I'll get the boys.  Hold on son, I'll be back for you.
(horrified) Me!
And if they get you on the floor  watch out for your brisket.
(hopefully) Oh, they seem all right to me.
That's what they want you to think.  All coppers are villains.
(calling) Would you two like a cup of tea?
You see, sly villains.
(miserable) No thanks, Mr. Sergeant, sir.
We now have a CLOSE SHOT of POLICEMEN around the sergeant desk.
So you just brought the old chap out  of the crowd for his own good.
Yeah, but he insisted on us bringing  him to the station.
Well, he can't stop here.
Shot of GRANDFATHER watching POLICEMEN intently and mutte words as he does.
What are you doing?
Lip reading.
What are they saying?
Nothing good.
The POLICEMEN make a move towards GRANDFATHER and RINGO.
Well son, it's now or never.
He jumps to his feet and scurries towards the door.
All right, you paid assassins. Johnny  McCartney'll give you a run for your  threepence ha'penny.
He dashes out of the door followed by the POLICEMAN who h his pile of photos.
Now, what's he up to?
He's allergic to Bobbies, especially  English Bobbies.
The POLICEMAN with the photos returns.
(Irish accent) Your man disappeared like a leveret  over a hill.
Turncoat!
The POLICEMEN turn on RINGO and walk towards him.
Mother!

GRANDFATHER is running at top speed down the street. He i breathing heavily and runs as if pursued by the hounds of hell. The street however is entirely empty and no one is  even in sight. As he reaches the top of the street he pau and turning, looks around him. From his P.O.V. we see jus how empty the street is and heaving a sigh of relief  GRANDFATHER cackles to himself. His triumph is short live At this precise moment down the street comes a parade of  police vehicles, a Black Maria, an escorting police motor bike patrol and an ordinary squad car. The procession dra up and the street is full of policemen getting out of the Black Maria and squad car and off motor bikes. CLOSE-UP  GRANDFATHER's horrified face.
Be God, they've called up  reinforcements, the dragnet's out!

He dashes off wildly in the general direction of the thea He has been completely unnoticed by the policemen who are lining up for a last minute inspection by the inspector i charge. The inspector is like a commander-in-chief of a s head attack force. They smartly march off in the direction taken by GRANDFAT
(watching the clock) Only half an hour and you're on!
Can I say something?
The director clutches at any straw.
(hopefully) Yes, anything.
(earnestly) It's highly unlikely we'll be on...  I mean the law of averages are against  you and it seems that, etc., etc....
But his speech is drowned by the pitiful moans of the  DIRECTOR.
The four little boys from the canal are being driven away the security guard.
(going back into  theatre) I'll have the hides off of you lot.
The kids retreat as GRANDFATHER pants into shot, ignoring the kids he enters the stage door but in a second he is o again, grasped firmly by the collar by the security guard
You ought to be ashamed of yourself.  Go home!
I must see Pauly.
Go home then and see him on the telly.
The GUARD re-enters the stage door. GRANDFATHER looks around him and sees the four kids. He  hustles over and after a whispered conference we hear his offer.
Can you fix him for me?
Yeah.
Sixpence.
Each?
GRANDFATHER is about to argue.
Oh, all right.
And in advance.
(disgusted) Mercenary!
But he hands over the money. The kids rush in the stage d and after a moment the furious GUARD chases them out and  down the alley. GRANDFATHER, chuckling, nips in the door.

head_text.subj: INTERIOR T.V. CONTROL ROOM ON STAGE

text: GRANDFATHER is being chased by several studio attendants; is dodging behind equipment. He finally gets on a sound b trolley and uses it as a weapon to keep his pursuers at b
The DIRECTOR, BOYS, and NORM and SHAKE see GRANDFATHER on the monitors. They dash out of the room and on to the stage.
(shouting) It's all right, leave him alone.
Grandad, where's Ringo?
The police have the poor unfortunate  lad in the Bridewell.
The police station.
He'll be pulp by now.
What are we waiting for?
Come here.
PAUL, JOHN and GEORGE rush off.
We've only got twenty minutes.

PAUL, JOHN and GEORGE come running down the street in sin file, their knees  high in the air, they skid to a halt a the police station and without pausing they dash inside.  After a moment they reappear -- only this time RINGO is b them. They dash off down the street. They are followed at once by ten POLICEMEN also in single file. They are also pounding along knees high in the air. The BOYS and the coppers disappear around the corner. At  once, they reappear from the other direction, then run do the street still followed by the policemen. When they reach the police station another group of polic bars their way so they are forced to run up the stairs an inside.

The DESK SERGEANT is standing behind his desk looking ver surprised. At this moment the boys run in and stand panting in front the desk. Before the SERGEANT can start speaking the pursuing POLIC arrive. They, too, are out of breath.
What is all this?
(heaving and panting) Hold on until we get our breath.
The BOYS and POLICEMEN pant on until JOHN seems to have  recovered.
All right now?
Sure. (to boys) Ready?
The BOYS nod and without further ado they turn and run th the surprised rank of POLICEMEN and out into the street.

Shots of BOYS being pursued (still in single file) by pol including the sergeant with one shot where the BOYS are  chasing the POLICEMEN. Finally, as they approach the theatre, they are seen by t girl fans who swarm around the police, over running them. The boys grin to each other and are about to make off whe from their P.O.V. we see the INSPECTOR and POLICEMEN bloc it.
Ah well, it was worth a try.
(calling to Sergeant) What do you think you're up to?
Arrest those boys, sir.
That's all we need to start a real  riot! (to Boys) Come on lads, they're waiting for  you.

The Inspector now hustles the BOYS through the crowds and through the main entrance of the theatre where SHAKE and  NORM are waiting. NORM looks suspiciously at RINGO who is still wearing his cap. RINGO whips it off and NORM deligh hugs him. The BOYS dash through the stalls entrance and o stage. The DIRECTOR sees them and bursts into tears with  relief. NORM hustles the lads into the wings to be change into their show costumes. All around them last-minute  preparations are going on.
Boys, you don't know what this means  to me. If you hadn't come back it  would have been the epilogue or the  news in Welsh for life.
Aren't you supposed to be in that  box?
The DIRECTOR gives NORM a final glare and dashes off.
And another thing, where's that old  mixer?
Here, Pauly.
And sitting on a box sadly chastened sits GRANDFATHER.
Well, I got a few things to say to  you, two-faced John McCartney.
Aw, leave him alone Paul, he's back,  isn't he? And it's not his fault  he's old.
(hotly) What's old got to do with it?
You needn't bother.
Y'what?
Practising to be thick-headed, you're  there already.
Look he's a mixer and a trouble maker!
That's right, but he's only asking  us to pay attention to him, aren't  you?
From JOHN's P.O.V. we see GRANDFATHER. He looks what he i a tired old man.

You see. (to Grandad) You know your trouble -- you should  have gone West to America. You'd  have wound up a Senior Citizen of  Boston. As it is you took the wrong  turning and what happened, you're a  lonely old man from Liverpool.
(fighting back) But I'm clean.
The BOYS giggle and slap him on the back.

We see the audience of girls streaming in and settling do in their places for the show. There is the usual business getting the show ready and we see SHOTS of the girls' fac then JOHN, PAUL, RINGO and GEORGE looking at them. At las on cue from the floor manager the BOYS start their act to the audience's screams. During the number we constantly CUT away to the audience  with various SHOTS of the ecstatic girls. In the middle o these shots we see NORM standing at the side of the audie his face glowing with satisfaction. We follow his gaze an from NORM'S P.O.V. we see GRANDFATHER handcuffed to SHAKE but in spite of this, the old man is enjoying himself. The BOYS now perform a medley of numbers, i.e., a little all the songs we have heard during the story. This gives impression of a full set and we finish after their bows.  While they are doing so they look again in the general  direction of SHAKE and GRANDFATHER and from their P.O.V., see SHAKE is beating time to the music but from his wrist dangles an empty set of handcuffs. GRANDFATHER has gone a As the BOYS are reacting to GRANDFATHER's disappearance o again, the trap door on the stage opens and GRANDFATHER  appears in the centre of the group as they finish their a and take their final bows.
NORM is waiting for the boys. With him are two studio  attendants carrying the boys' luggage. As the BOYS excite appear he speaks to them.
I've got the stuff. Come here.
Aren't we...
No, we're not!
He hurries them along.
The office was on the phone, they  think it'd be better if we pushed  straight to Wolverhampton.
Tonight? We can't make it...
You've got a midnight matinee.
Now, look here, Norm...
No, you look here, John. I've only  one thing to say to you.
What?
You're a swine. So hurry up... we're  travelling!
NORM turns down a side exit where the door is open to the field. In it is an eight-passenger helicopter.
The BOYS and NORM come out of the building and start to r towards the helicopter.
(looking behind him) Where's my grandfather?
(arriving at helicopter  door) Don't start. Look.
The boys look in the passenger bay and there is GRANDFATH He is still handcuffed to SHAKE but clutching his pile of photos.
(beckoning them in  with his free hand  which holds the photos) Come on, you're hanging up the parade.
The boys shout "Get rid of those things, etc."

The final shot is of the helicopter rising up (SHOT FROM  BELOW). As it disappears, a shower of photos come from it window. We cut to a CLOSE-UP of one signed photo as it hits the g and SUPER the closing credits over it.
